title: Is whaling the biggest threat to whales? | Environment | The Guardian
summary: fishing nets and tackle kill 300,000 whales and dolphins every year .

documents.title: my verdict
text: for some species , notably minke whales , small scale whaling offers little threat to their immediate survival .
for many others , whaling offers no threat at all as they are off limits to hunters .
in this sense , whales are perhaps the pandas of the oceans .
drawing disproportionate funding and attention to a cause that is as much moral as conservation .
many more whales die from entanglement in fishing lines and nets than on the harpoon .
these impacts affect all whales species , from the relatively common to the rare .

in terms of numerical impact , the death of just three north atlantic right whales ( 0.7 % of the species ) in shipping or fishing accidents is comparable to the entire annual norwegian minke whale quota .
with a few exceptions , extinctions happen by one thousand cuts .
the cumulative effects of noise , shipping , climate change and fishing mean that the oceans have become an increasingly inhospitable place for all whale species .
i wonder what the result would be if the force of moral objection applied to whaling was turned upon gill netting or the shipping industry ?
what technological solutions would appear and how many whales might be saved ?

documents.title: sustainable whaling ?
text: many of those who object to whaling on moral grounds accept that hunting some species is not necessarily a threat to their survival .
norway , which operates the world 's only outwardly commercial whaling fleet , says its minke whale quota is sustainable and set on the basis of scientific advice given to the iwc .
stocks of minke whale that we harvest in the northeast atlantic and around jan mayen total 108,000 animals .
for 2013 , a quota is set of 1286 animals .
this is the same as the quota for 2010-2012 .
the stock of minke whales off iceland and the faeroe islands , the central atlantic stock , is estimated to number 71,000 animals . ''
last year , japan 's northern pacific hunt for dolphins and whales was found to be unsustainable by the environmental investigation agency .
this is an interesting point : ocean alliance ( @ ocean alliance ) .
@ karlmathiesen please add pollution to your list of threats to whales in the @ twitterid : is pollution a big factor for the health of whales ?

the iwc says : this is a complex issue given the huge number of synthetic chemicals introduced into the environment , the difficulty in establishing whether they have an effect and quantifying any effects detected .
however , as agreed at a specialist workshop in 1995 , there were sufficient indications from other taxa of potential damaging effects on health ( e.g .
with respect to greater susceptibility to disease and poorer reproductive success ) to warrant concern for cetaceans . ''
but as paul jepson said earlier , chemical pollutants normally affect predators that feed on animals higher up the food chain .
dangerous toxins are passed on from prey to predator in ever accumulating amounts .
dolphins are definitely exposed to this threat , but whales , which mainly eat tiny crustaceans , are exposed to less of the build up of chemicals .

documents.title: your comments
text: tonkatsu 16 september 2014 11:51am it 's a distraction by a well meaning group of people who want a cause that 's easy to follow ( because it does n't involve any changes to your lifestyle , or put you in conflict with anyone you know directly , but you still get to feel outraged and good about yourself for it .

make no mistakes , whaling should be stopped - but the 800 or so , non endangered , minke whales killed every year are becoming a bit like the panda of the oceans a huge amount of international focus on what is actually a minuscule part of the vast damage we are doing to the planet .
as a general population ( things like the fukushima problem aside ) japanese tend to be very good at things like recycling and can be very eco-conscious .
i think cetaceans are probably more at threat from the damage we ( not just the japanese ) are doing to the oceans in general than from a few hunts .

ieyasutokugawa 16 september 2014 11:47am given that modern day whaling objectively poses absolutely no threat to the viability of any targeted whale stock , why is any focus being placed on the issue ?
the moratorium on commercial whaling was implemented as a temporary measure to allow the recovery of threatened whale stocks to the point at which they could again be harvested sustainably .
for a great many species , such as the minke and humpback , this point has long since been achieved .
the moratorium should have been lifted accordingly , however , it remains in place due to the obstructionist activities of ideologically motivated prohibitionists who have hijacked the iwc .
that organisation has been rendered utterly dysfunctional by such recalcitrants , which is why we have this `` whaling issue '' today despite its irrelevance to conservation .
whilst the anti-whaling movement once had legitimacy and was a bona fide conservation cause , today it could not be further from its credible roots .
it has become the realm of feel-good , hypocritical pontification and also violent animal rights extremism .
the sooner the moratorium on commercial whaling is lifted in accordance with science and reason , the sooner this non-issue will become just that - a non-issue .

misslaurar 16 september 2014 11:39am i think it is right to focus on the whale sanctuary right now because it should , in theory , be a quick and easy win that will have a massive impact on the whale population and subsequent biodiversity .
get that done and then you can start un the infrastructure of all the many , industries , countries and individuals who are damaging the oceans in such a myriad of different ways .
if we did it the other way round , they 'd be no whales left by the time we got round to it .
how did your country vote on the expansion of greenland 's indigenous whaling ?
noise pollution the level of noise in our oceans has increased dramatically in recent decades and this effects almost every area of whale life , says ken collins of the university of southampton .
blue whales used to be able to talk to each other across the pacific ocean , '' he says .
but not any more . ''
he says the impact of noise on human health is well documented .
just think about noise on land and how it affects every aspect of your life .
for whales , sound is more important than sight . ''
strandings are an obvious example of deaths related to noise .
but collins says the subtler impacts of noise , while harder to quantify , may be more insidious .
noise pollution interferes with the social communication of whales , making it more difficult to find mates , says collins .
this is especially important in an ocean that contains far fewer potential partners than it once did .
blue whales have been documented to have changed the frequency of their songs in order to try and pierce through the noise .
while admitting to being a confirmed anti-whaler '' , collins says that the effects of human industry , shipping , fishing and noise probably represent greater conservation concerns than whaling .
there are a number of problems that go unnoticed , '' he says .

documents.title: other threats to whales
text: ship strikes it is tremendously difficult to estimate the number of whales killed by colliding with ships , says the iwc , because it most often happens without the knowledge of the crew or it is not reported .
for every incident that is observed and reported there will be many others that are missed .
this makes assessing the conservation implications of ship strikes very difficult . ''
this is a significant problem for species like the north atlantic right whale of which there are only around 440 left .
this species main habitat is the busy waters off the east coast of the usa and canada , the mortality rate is particularly high compared to the overall population size .
it is thought that mortality due to ship strikes may make the difference between extinction and survival for this species '' .
climate change warmer oceans and melting sea ice threaten the habitat of some species of whale , especially in the arctic .
it will open the area up to industrialisation and shipping , meaning the proxy sanctuary of the frozen north will no longer be safe .
the international union for conservation of nature ( iucn ) says the drastic '' decline of beluga whales due to hunting and habitat loss could be exacerbated by the effects of climate change .

documents.title: fishing nets and tackle kill 300,000 whales and dolphins every year
text: entanglement in fishing tackle is not only a far crueler and more drawn out death than for the vast majority of whaling victims .
entanglement affects species without concern for their conservation status , it also kills in numbers that appear to dwarf the annual whale cull .
a 2013 study found that entanglement had killed 43 % of whales in which the cause of death could be identified .

in 2012 , a yale environment report noted that : scientists examining scars on whale skin estimate that 82 percent of north atlantic right whales and about half of endangered humpbacks between cape cod and nova scotia have become entangled at least once . ''
the term entanglement refers to animals becoming caught in gear and towing it along with them , sometimes for months or years .
bycatch is the unintentional capture of small cetaceans in fishing nets .
the total number of whales , dolphins and porpoises killed annually as bycatch is unknown , but the standard estimate of around 300,000 comes from a 2006 duke university study .
the vast majority of these are caused by gill nets .
estimates for cetacean entanglement made by expanding data on by-catch from us fishing fleet to match number of boats worldwide .
et .
al .
the study does not specify the exact number of whales killed by entanglement , so the numbers are not directly comparable to the 1500 or so whales killed each year by whaling .
but evidence that 43 % of whales die wrapped in fishing nets and ropes , indicates that this problem is of another order altogether when compared to whaling .
the icelandic minister of fisheries , sigurður ingi jóhannsson , has responded to an international initiative calling upon it to cease its whaling practices , saying that its cull is sustainable .
i think that in the past few years we have been too shy about [ our sustainable whaling practices ] and i think it 's really burned us , '' jóhannsson told iceland 's ruv news .
people and companies have maintained for a long time [ that whaling has damaged the reputation of icelanders ] and pitted tourism and whale watching against whaling .
but if we look at this rationally , and analyse the numbers , these two industries run really well alongside one another . ''
yesterday the eu , us , australia , brazil , israel and new zealand issued a joint demarche which raised concerns over the country 's expanded whaling programme .

the statement said : we are especially troubled by iceland 's harvestof 125 fin whales in 2009 , 148 fin whales in 2010 , and 134 fin whales in 2013 , all of which are a significant increase from the seven fin whales harvested over the 20 years prior to 2009 .
the current 5 year quota of 770 fin whales is considered unsustainable under iwc stock assessment methods .
we encourage the government of iceland to adhere to the internationally agreed moratorium on commercial whaling and to re-examine the decision to continue to issue fin and minke whale quotas . ''
it also questioned iceland 's international trade in whale products .

the country currently opts out of the controls set by the convention on international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora ( cites ) , this allows it to trade some products from fin and minke whales .

signatories said : we are not convinced that iceland 's harvest and subsequent trade of fin whales meets any domestic market demand or need ; it also undermines effective international cetacean conservation efforts . ''
the japanese whale hunt takes whales at an unsustainable rate , says paul jepson , a marine mammal veterinarian at the zoological society of london ( zsl ) .
but a lot of the whaling done by north atlantic whaling countries is probably sustainable numerically '' .
levels of minke whales remain high in the region because historical whalers did not harvest them , instead focussing on larger , more lucrative species .
thus , the whalers of norway , iceland and greenland may be having limited conservation impact on the species .
however , says jepson , most people would agree that any level of whaling is undesirable '' .
he says a major humane and conservation issue is entanglement , whereby whales become enmeshed in discarded fishing nets and tackle .
the effect of this can be a long , painful death as the whale 's growth becomes constricted by the ropes around it and its ability to feed becomes more inhibited .
on average , northern atlantic right whales take six months to die from chronic entanglement .
unlike whaling , entanglement is indiscriminate in which species it kills .
this makes it a major threat for the rarest species of whale .
the same goes for collisions with ships .
jepson says rare northern atlantic right and bowhead whales are at risk in the region 's heavily industrialised oceans .
noise pollution is also a well documented cause of whale deaths , with links to industrial and naval sonar well established .
in 2002 , jepson worked on a mass stranding of deep diving beaked whales in the canary islands .
he said autopsies of the animals revealed pathology similar to a diver with the bends , indicating the animals had been driven from the depths .
naval exercises testing sonar to track submarines was blamed for the animals ' suicidal behaviour .
but the number of whales killed in strandings is comparatively small .
globally strandings are rare events , '' says jepson .
they may not be a big conservation problem . ''

jepson says new research , to be released next year , into the chemical pollution of the marine food chain has found that the levels of polychlorinated biphenyls ( pcbs ) in dolphin species was high enough to damage reproduction .
he said efforts to stop these chemicals leaking into the ocean were failing .
while this does not effect large whale species that feed on animals lower down the food chain in deep ocean environments , the predatory cetaceans were facing a distinct threat .
this is a much , much bigger conservation issue than whaling , '' says jepson .

documents.title: whaling statistics
text: the number of whales killed by whaling is undoubtedly on the rise , despite the moratorium on commercial whaling .
since 1986 , whalers have taken 30,000 animals .
whales killed under the aus of science '' made up around a third of the 1500 or so whales hunted last year , according to wwf .
the number of whales killed per year has crept back to pre-moratorium levels .
whaling permits by numbers whaling permits are issued under the iwc for a variety of reasons .
since 1986 japan , iceland and norway have operated research programmes that demand permits to hunt whales on a scientific basis .
other permits are issued to indigenous communities that have traditionally hunted whales .
the majority of permits are issued for relatively common minke and fin whales .
quotas are set by the iwc on the basis of sustainability , although this is a matter of dispute .
whaling permits for indigenous whalers allowed around 1700 whales of various species to be taken between 2008 and 2012 .
japan 's now illegal jarpa ii programme had permits to take 850±10 % antarctic minke whales , 50 fin whales and 50 humpback whales annually .
it rarely came near meeting this quota , partly because of the intervention of sea shepherd protesters .
japan has killed more than 10,000 whales since the 1986 moratorium came into effect .
as mentioned , iceland 's current five year quota is 770 fin whales .
norway 's quota for 2013 was 1286 animals .
it now sets this limit itself as part of a commercial whaling operation outside the convention .
norway says its quota is based on the same principles of sustainability the iwc uses .

documents.title: welcome to the eco audit
text: the international whaling commission ( iwc ) is discussing proposals which could put an end to japan 's maligned southern ocean whale hunt and create a massive new reserve for migratory whales in the atlantic .
the 88 member states will today vote on the creation of a 50 million square mile reserve that would preserve a corridor where whales could breed and migrate free from the threat of harpoons .
tomorrow it will consider a new zealand proposal that would block japan 's desire to recommence its outlawed summer hunt in the southern ocean .
the biennial meetings of the 88 member states of the iwc dominate the whale conservation agenda .
wwf prioritises whaling at the top of its list of threats to the survival of cetacean species and sea shepherd has made stopping whaling its singular priority .
but how does whaling at current levels compare to the number of animals killed by shipping collisions or the loss of habitat ?
should our focus be broader ?

bulletin.text: As countries meet in Slovenia to discuss proposals for whale conservation the headlines are dominated by the activities of whaling nations. Karl Mathiesen, with your help, investigates whether we're right to focus so much on whaling compared to other threats, from shipping to climate change.
